chatgpt_double_star.new_statement: Government should ensure every resident can obtain timely primary, preventive, emergency, and mental health care without facing unaffordable bills, using an automatically available public plan or guarantee as the default. It should set and enforce fair pricing, minimum coverage standards, and quality reporting to curb waste and surprise costs, while allowing regulated private plans to offer supplemental benefits and compete on service. Reforms should be phased, focus on simplifying enrollment and billing, and invest in rural access and prevention so the system remains sustainable and broadly acceptable.

chatgpt_double_star_rankings.new_statement: Government should guarantee a universal, affordable baseline of essential care—including preventive, emergency, mental‑health, and catastrophic coverage—so no one is denied treatment or driven into medical bankruptcy. Within that floor, it should set clear quality standards and enforce transparent pricing, while using streamlined administration and evidence‑based, phased reforms to control costs. Regulated private plans can offer supplemental options and compete on service and innovation, supported by public–private and local partnerships that strengthen rural and vulnerable communities and protect taxpayers.

chatgpt_double_star_personas.new_statement: Government should ensure every American has access to essential primary, preventive, emergency, and mental-health care, with strong protection against catastrophic costs so no family faces medical bankruptcy. It should set clear, transparent standards for pricing and quality, reduce administrative waste, and use fair cost-sharing and targeted support for seniors, veterans, rural areas, and working families. Private doctors and insurers should remain part of the system through regulated competition and optional supplemental coverage, while reforms are phased in and measured to protect taxpayers, small businesses, and patient choice.
